awd_titl_txt: Science and Integrated Language Plus Computational Thinking and Modeling with English Learners
awd_abstract_narration:
As computing has become integral to the practice of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM), the STEM + Computing Partnerships program seeks to address emerging challenges in computational STEM areas through the applied integration of computational thinking (CT) and computing activities within STEM teaching and learning in early childhood education through high school. This project is a research and development effort aimed at developing a yearlong science curriculum aligned to the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) with a focus on English learners (ELs) that integrates computational modeling. The project will integrate computational models in online environments using StarLogo Nova to allow all students, including ELs, to model causal relationships that explain the studied phenomena. Plans are to enhance and integrate StarLogo Nova, a block-based programming environment with an agent-based simulation engine for modeling complex systems. Using the enhanced StarLogo Nova, the project will embed CT throughout the yearlong NGSS-aligned curriculum for students and teachers. 

The project will take place in Elizabeth Public Schools in Elizabeth, New Jersey (NJ), and Metro Nashville Public Schools in Nashville, Tennessee (TN). These are two distinct sites with diverse student populations. NJ adopted the NGSS and is currently working out implementation plans, whereas TN represents states that have not adopted the NGSS. The study has two main goals: (1) to investigate feasibility of implementation of the curriculum model in classrooms; and (2) to investigate the extent to which the curriculum promotes student learning outcomes. To achieve the first goal in terms of feasibility of classroom implementation, the project will examine the following research questions: (1) To what extent and how do elementary school teachers support students' engagement in computational modeling?; (2) To what extent and how do students engage in computational modeling?; and (3) What design features of the curriculum and software support students' engagement in computational modeling? Data gathering strategies will include focus groups, field notes to document teachers' feedback, and classroom observations, including videotaping. To achieve the second goal in terms of student learning outcomes, the project will examine the following questions: (4) How do students' understanding of the causal relationships underlying phenomena evolve as they engage in physical, diagrammatic, and computational modeling over the year?; and (5) How do students' understanding of key aspects of CT (e.g., abstraction, pattern generalization, representational competence, modularization, algorithmic notions of flow of control, and conditional logic) evolve as they engage in computational modeling over the full-year curriculum? To measure student learning outcomes, the project will use student assessments of science and CT. A principal outcome of this project will be a field-tested and research-informed model that integrates (a) science learning, (b) language learning, and (c) infusion of critical CT constructs and ideas. An external evaluation will include formative and summative components to provide an independent perspective on the project's work, contributions, and quality of outcomes in terms of design critique, research audit, products review, and collaboration assessment.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of the project, "Science And Integrated Language Plus Computational Thinking and Modeling with English Learners" (SAIL+CTM with ELs), was to expand and refine a yearlong fifth-grade NGSS-designed curriculum with a focus on ELs by integrating computational thinking and modeling. The goals of the project were to (1) develop the SAIL+CTM curriculum, (2) investigate feasibility of implementation of the curriculum in classrooms, and (3) investigate the extent to which the curriculum promotes student learning outcomes in both science and CTM.

 

The SAIL+CTM curriculum built on and synergized two ongoing projects: ?Science And Integrated Language? (SAIL) and StarLogo Nova. A key feature of the SAIL curriculum is the NGSS practice of modeling. In each of the four units in the SAIL curriculum, students make sense of phenomena and represent their ideas using physical models in material environments and diagrammatic models in print environments. The SAIL+CTM curriculum expanded the SAIL curriculum to integrate computational models in online environments using StarLogo Nova, a blocks-based programming environment with an agent-based simulation engine for modeling complex systems (see Figure 1).

 

In the SAIL+CTM curriculum, physical, diagrammatic, and computational models are incorporated in each of the four SAIL units, which together make up a yearlong fifth-grade curriculum (see Figure 2). Each type of model has affordances and limitations. For example, whereas diagrammatic models allow students to represent processes too small to see (e.g., using arrows to represent gas particles moving freely), computational models allow students to iteratively test and revise their ideas about the mechanisms underlying phenomena (e.g., testing ideas about how microbes decompose a solid banana and produce gas particles).

 

Unit 1:  What happens to our garbage? (Structure and properties of matter)

Unit 2:  Why did the tiger salamanders disappear? (Ecosystems)

Unit 3:  Why does it matter if I drink tap water or bottled water? (Earth?s systems)

Unit 4:  Why do falling stars fall? (Space systems)

 

We field-tested initial, revised, and final versions of the curriculum in classrooms to ensure that the materials could be implemented by teachers with varying levels of experience in science, CT, and EL teaching. Teachers were able to implement the curriculum with the support of professional development workshops and became more comfortable and proficient in their implementation over time. Students improved from pre- to post-assessments in both science and CT. All students, regardless of EL classification, improved from pre- to post- assessments in both science and CT.

 

We highlight four noteworthy contributions of the project. First, we developed teacher and student curriculum materials using StarLogo Nova. The innovative extensions to StarLogo Nova developed as part of the project provide a template for other blocks-based, agent-based programming environments that focus on modeling complex systems and will enable other developers, researchers, teachers, and students to leverage the software for their own purposes.

 

Second, modeling is a key disciplinary practice across subject areas that offers multimodal affordances to all students, especially ELs. However, multimodality is viewed differently across disciplines with ELs. In traditional thinking, STEM disciplines viewed multimodality (e.g., diagrams, symbols, code, dynamic visualization, graphs) as essential, whereas EL education viewed multimodality as supports or scaffolds toward language (i.e., listening, speaking, reading, writing). This project illustrates contemporary thinking in which multimodality is essential to engagement in STEM disciplines and particularly beneficial to ELs.

 

Third, the project includes all students, especially ELs, in learning science and developing CT in elementary school. Computational modeling provides a powerful vehicle for supporting the NGSS in elementary science instruction. From a science education perspective, prior efforts to design and test NGSS-aligned curriculum at the elementary level are limited. From a CT perspective, prior efforts to design and test computational modeling at the elementary level are also limited. As fifth grade is often the final grade in elementary schools or the first grade in middle schools, this project is intended to ensure that all students, including ELs, experience NGSS-aligned science and CT instruction as they advance into their secondary education.

 

Finally, the education system is changing rapidly due to three emerging forces: (a) traditional minority groups are now the majority and English learners (ELs) make up the fastest growing subgroup in the nation, (b) current standards in STEM subjects are academically rigorous, and (c) technological innovations are advancing fast. The reality of these three emerging forces in the lives of students and teachers compels the research community to figure out the nexus of NGSS science and CT with ELs. By working at this nexus, the project produced research results and curricular products that contribute, separately and collectively, to science education, computer science education, and EL education.
